QAPair.Question: What is (are) Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Episcleritis is irritation and inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye. It is not an infection.

QAPair.Question: What causes Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Episcleritis is a common condition. In most cases the problem is mild and vision is normal. The cause is often unknown. But, it may occur with certain diseases, such as: Herpes zoster , Rheumatoid arthritis , Sjögren syndrome , Syphilis, Tuberculosis ,

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms include: A pink or purple color to the normally white part of the eye, Eye pain , Eye tenderness, Sensitivity to light , Tearing of the eye ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Your health care provider will do an eye exam to diagnose the disorder. Most of the time, no special tests are needed.

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: The condition most often goes away on its own in 1 to 2 weeks. Using corticosteroid eye drops may help ease the symptoms faster.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Episcleritis most often improves without treatment. However, treatment may make symptoms go away sooner.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: In some cases, the condition may return. Rarely, irritation and inflammation of the white part of the eye may develop. This is called scleritis.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Episcleritis ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your provider if you have symptoms of episcleritis that last for more than 2 weeks. Get checked again if your pain gets worse or you have problems with your vision.
